ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: NLP skill, sementic analysis

Overview survey of many NLP topics including but not limited to: Embeddings, Logistic Regression, Semantics, Syntax, Neural Networks, Transformers, HMM, Naive Bayes, RNN, LSTM, GRU, and other misc topics.

Grammar, NLP common sense, NLP cutting edge research, NLP models and their strengths/weaknesses, different neural networks, and mathematical theories behind formula and algorithms, machine translation, transformers.
Neural nets
Traditional and neural NLP
Some NLP techniques, algorithms.
N gram language models, hidden Markov models, linguistic knowledge, machine translation, part of speech tagging, neural networks, pytorch

Introduction to linguistics, NLP tasks, and neural networks. Lectures cover a wide breadth of content. Psets include implementing a part of speech tagger, working through the math of MLE for sentences, LSTM, and a transformer for translating language.
Greater insight into some previous common / modern techniques in NLP
Knowledges about natural language processing. And, programming skills to use pytorch and other deep learning libraries. Thanks.
NLP
The wide variety of different NLP applications, research, and methods.
NLP techniques

The introduction to the course covers some of the challenges of NLP, including linguistic ambiguity, syntactic relations, and so on.
The first half of the semester was focused on probabilistic models (e.g. logistic regression, naive Bayes, HMMs) for NLP tasks.
The second half was focused on neural methods (e.g. RNNs, LSTMs, transformers) and some of the common infrastructure (e.g. Huggingface).
Parsing, NLp related coding
Introductions to NLP, Language Modeling, Text Classification, Deep Learning, Lexical Semantics, Neural Networks, Machine Translation.
Everything about NLP! especially in its application in machine translation
I learned about various ML techniques and other techniques for natural language processing. A wide variety (so much that I cannot go into detail)
We learnt the fundamentals of NLP and especially how Deep Learning and ML methods may be applied to the field.
I gained a tremendous amount of knowledge in machine learning, especially on its application to real world use cases in processing languages.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: everything is great

Strengths: Interesting course to take as an introduction to NLP
Weaknesses: PSETs often had mistakes and final review/midterm review had mistakes as well that had to be resolved by students. 

Improvement: Have revised PSETs and review sheets that are verified to be correct, make PSETs more thorough and not require a lot of online searching to find the solution.

This course is highly informative, useful, and intriguing. It covers many areas of NLP that students may be interested in, but I believe it could be improve by slowing the pace a little bit and having a smaller classroom such that we could hear the instructor better.

Strengths: Broad overview. A survey of topics. Weaknesses: Lectures are hard to pay attention to. Homework assignments are not really related to lecture content (which to be fair was made clear at the beginning of the semester).

Strengths: really interesting material, great teaching staff, practical psets, feeling that youre really learning about cutting edge research 

Weaknesses: sometimes I wish there were more smaller assignments just because it felt like many topics I understood conceptually but didnt really know how to implement. I also wish that the last assignment had less content but also less pre-provided code - a lot of it was given but I would have preferred to do more from scratch.

Most annoying thing to me was how the TAs would handle Piazza questions. Every question was answered with either go read it in the book or with sometimes snarky-seeming what do you think?-style answers that did not help at all.
very meaningful problem sets that help learning the material

Strengths: Drago is an expert in the field, and learning about neural nets through application in machine translation or sentiment analysis is a nice, concrete way to learn about machine learning at an intro-intermediate level. There are funny moments in class where we're shown NLP memes or hilarious example sentences in linguistics! He's a very kind professor and was lenient on using late days for psets. Weaknesses: The TF's were relatively active on the discussion board (Piazza) to answer questions. Since a lot of content is covered, however, I end up missing many topics mentioned in class that I have to look up later, especially if it's expected we fully implement a process for a pset. Even with the piazza posts, I felt there could have been more office hours spread throughout the week (maybe 1 hour slots twice a week instead of one 2 hour slot so more days of the week are covered). The lecture slides are numbered but not taught in the same number order, meaning it could be hard to keep track of notes and lecture slides if you wanted to review past material later on.

I think the lecture slides were a bit messy
However, I think overall the class was well taught and Drago is a nice person

Strengths: clear format, reasonable workload, and interesting materials.
Weakness: none
All good

Strengths: We have a professor who is very knowledgeable in this area and has very good insights during lectures.
Weaknesses: We only skim a lot of the material leaving more to be desired in terms of understanding NLP more deeply. Perhaps we could cut off material that isn't as interesting or relevant and spend that time to learn things that are interesting more deeply.
Weakness: I think the structure of the course is pretty unclear. The slides are not well-organized, either.

Strengths:
- Covered lots of material
- Did not require lots of background in linguistics to understand material
- Interesting concepts in homework

Weaknesses:
- I found lectures to be very boring
- Homework problems were sometimes poorly specified
I think it would have been better if we had more samples codes. Also some of the slides are nice but it could help if we have some additional notes. Also it would help if we had recordings
The course is well organized and challenging. The contents are interesting.

Strengths: great balance and programming work and knowledge base. The guest lecture was quite interesting

Weakness: I know it's hard to cover all on linguistics plus computer science in just one semester, but maybe can focus less on linguistics but more on the CS techniques.
making lectures available with a recording could be very nice. Otherwise, format was good.

I think the assignments can be improved with more focus on programming aspects in class. Perhaps having an extra class in the week totally focused on programming, for instance on teaching Pytorch would have been extremely helpful.
This course serves as a broad overview and introduction to NLP. However, I think the lecture quality could be improved. The lectures are way too fast.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: yes
If you enjoy NLP, yes it brings interesting topics. As a survey course it is also not bad for learning all about NLP.
Yes. Although it is difficult, it is rewarding, TAs and the professor have been incredibly accessible.
Yes very interesting material

Yes if you want to learn about NLP, but possibly not if you've already taken LING 227, in which case many things will be repeat (and Bob Frank's explanations of a lot of the dynamic programming algorithms are better in my opinion, because he walks you through examples). But also maybe review is good. The HW assignments for NLP do provide more opportunities for interacting with machine learning frameworks like pytorch, though I don't feel like I actually learned how to use them.
Absolutely- the material was fascinating and combines many different areas of linguistics and CS. I feel like I have a very strong background if I wish to do more work or research in this field.
I would. The concepts are interesting and Professor is kind and helpful.
Yes I think Drago is a great professor and he delivers the material very well

This is a solid CS elective for getting a deep dive into the field of NLP but by no means an easy one, and you should take it only if you really want to get an introduction to NLP and machine learning. The lectures go by fast, and the psets require a lot of self-teaching.
Yes, if youre interested in NLP / CS / linguistics  itll become very popular I believe
Yes. I will recommend this course to other students. This course inspires my interests in NLP, and facilitates my understanding of multiple machine learning/ deep learning algorithms generally.
Yes

I would recommend it if they were interested in NLP broadly. I would however recommend other resources to supplement their learning and for them to do research/projects if they really wanted to learn more.
Yes, if he's interested in nLP

I would recommend this course to any student with an interest in computational linguistics or NLP. It was not overly challenging, and I feel like I learned enough to be able to implement basic NLP solutions myself. The lectures were sometimes a bit dense, but this was mostly a factor of how much material we needed to cover.
Yep I think its a good class. Very interesting.
Sure. NLP is really interesting.
Yes. This course builds a solid foundation for anyone interested in NLP
Yes. Good course for anyone interested in NLP.
Yes. It was interesting and I learned a lot about more than jsut NLP (the techniques behind it helped in other classes!)
Yes, I would.
